DD_Attribute.name: data_producer_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The data_producer_name element provides the name of the person who created the product.

DD_Attribute.name: data_provider_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The data_provider_name element provides the full name of the person who submitted the product to the library.

DD_Attribute.name: emission_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The emission_angle element provides the angle between the local vertical at the intercept point and a vector from the intercept point to the sensor.
DD_Attribute.comment: N/A for some measurement_geometry_types. Will make it optional in the class.

DD_Attribute.name: incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The incidence_angle element provides the angle between the local vertical at the intercept point and a vector from the intercept point to the detector.
DD_Attribute.comment: N/A for some measurement_geometry_types. Will make it optional in the class.

DD_Attribute.name: material_common_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The material_common_name element gives the specific name of the specimen material, as specifically as it is known. For example, if a specimen is pure olivine, put "Olivine". If a specimen is a mixture of kaolinite and opal, put "Kaolinite/Opal". Indicate if "Unidentified".
DD_Attribute.comment: I would like these to be searchable items/keywords. If something like "Kaolinite/Opal" is included, could it be found by only searching for "opal" or would it have to be specifically searched for as "Kaolinite/Opal"? (AZ) Changed this from material_identification and made it optional. (EG)

DD_Attribute.name: material_origin
DD_Attribute.definition: The material_origin element identifies the origin of the specimen.
DD_Attribute.comment: Is it possible to organize these specimen classification attributes so that the form changes depending on which option they choose? Or by doing away with the whole hierarchical system, does that no longer matter? We could also put a N/A option on each of the subtypes so that if something's not a mineral (or whatever it may not be), they just have to fill in N/A. I'm still a bit unsure about the non-hierarchical idea as it relates to the classification. Also, once something is marked as "Unclassified", it's not going to have any further classification. Will they just have to fill in N/A for everything else after that?

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Natural value indicates that the specimen was not made in a laboratory.
The Synthetic value indicates that the specimen was made in a laboratory. A synthetic sample could be either a physical mixture of natural materials or a laboratory synthesized material.

DD_Attribute.name: material_state
DD_Attribute.definition: The material_state element identifies the physical state of the specimen.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Solid value indicates that the specimen is in the solid state.
The Liquid value indicates that the specimen is in the liquid state.
The Gas value indicates that the specimen is in the gas state.

DD_Attribute.name: material_subtype
DD_Attribute.definition: The material_subtype element identifies the material subtype of the specimen.
DD_Attribute.comment: Material_subtype does not have enumerated values because there are too many to list.

DD_Attribute.name: material_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The material_type element indicates the general type of the specimen.
DD_Attribute.comment: Every specimen will have a material_type unless it has a synthetic_origin of "hardware". Again, better value_meanings will have to come from Ray.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: tbd
tbd
tbd
Particulate matter, such as soil. The term "unconsolidated" is preferred to "soil" because soil implies organic material.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_atmosphere_composition
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_atmosphere_composition element identifies any gas(es) present in measurement environment.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_atmosphere_description
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_atmosphere_description decribes the atmospheric conditions through which the data was taken.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_atmosphere_pressure
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurment_atmosphere_pressure element provides the atmospheric pressure of measurement environment.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_atmosphere_temperature
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_atmosphere_temperature element provides the temperature of the measurement environment.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_date_time
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_date_time element identifies the date and time of the observation and measurement.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_geometry_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_geometry_type element identifies the type of geometry at which a measurement is taken.
DD_Attribute.comment: This is another element where an "other" option would be nice. Also, I'll need Ray to verify the definitions of each type.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Measurement taken when light is sent in to the specimen at a certain direction and received at a certain direction.
Measurement taken when light is sent in to the specimen at a certain direction and received in all directions (perhaps in an integrating sphere).
Measurement taken when light is sent in to the specimen at all directions and received in all directions (perhaps in an integrating sphere).
Measurement taken when light is sent in to the specimen at a certain direction and in a cone-like shape and received at a certain direction and in a cone-like shape.
The measurement geometry is unknown.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_notes
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_notes element contains relevant notes about how a measurement was made.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_reference_standard
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_reference_standard element identifies the standard object on which observations are performed in order to calibrate an instrument.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_source_description
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_source_description element identifies the source used for the measurement such as the type of lamp, heating element, laser, or radioactive source.

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_type element identifies the type of spectroscopy performed on a specimen.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Reflectance value indicates reflectance spectroscopy, the study of light as a function of wavelength that has been reflected or scattered from a material.
The Emission value indicates emission spectroscpy, which examines the wavelengths emitted by atoms or molecules during their transition from an excited state to a lower energy state.
The Raman value indicates Raman spectroscopy, which determines information about a material by studying the Raman scattering of monochromatic light off the material.
The X-Ray Fluorescence value indicates x-ray flourescence spectroscopy, which examines the emission of x-rays from a material previously bombarded with high energy x-rays or gamma rays.
The X-Ray Diffraction value indicates x-ray diffraction spectroscopy, which studies the diffraction patterns of x-rays scattered off a material.
LIBS (Laser-Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy) uses a highly energetic laser pulse as its excitation source to produce emission spectra.

DD_Attribute.name: mineral_subtype
DD_Attribute.definition: The mineral_subtype element identifies the mineral subtype of the specimen.
DD_Attribute.comment: Mineral_subtype does not have enumerated values because there are too many to list.

DD_Attribute.name: mineral_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The mineral_type element identifies the type of mineral to which the specimen belongs.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Native Element value indicates the specimen is a native element or an alloy.
The Sulfide value indicates the specimen is a sulfide.
The Oxide value indicates the specimen is an oxide.
The Halogenide value indicates the specimen is a halogenide.
The Carbonate value indicates the specimen is a carbonate.
The Nitrate/Iodate/Borate value indicates the specimen is a nitrate, iodate, or borate.
The Sulfate value indicates the specimen is a sulfate.
The Phosphate value indicates the specimen is a sulfate.
The Organic Compound value indicates the specimen is an organic compound.
The Nesosiliacte value indicates the specimen is a nesosilicate.
The Sorosilicate value indicates the specimen is a sorosilicate.
The Cyclosiliate value indicates the specimen is a sorosilicate.
The Inosilicate value indicates the specimen is a inosilicate.
The Phyllosilicate value indicates the specimen is a phyllosilicate.
The Tektosilicate value indicates the specimen is a tektosilicate.
The Unclassified value indicates that the specimen doesn't fit into any of these categories, but is still a mineral.

DD_Attribute.name: organic_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The organic_type element identifies the organic type to which the specimen belongs.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Biotic value indicates the specimen is a biotic organic material.
The Abiotic value indicates the specimen is an abiotic organic material.
The Inorganic value indicates the specimen is not an organic material.

DD_Attribute.name: phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The phase_angle element provides the angle between incidence and emission vectors.
DD_Attribute.comment: N/A for some measurement_geometry_types. Will make it optional in the class.

DD_Attribute.name: processing_description
DD_Attribute.definition: The processing_description element describes how a synthetic specimen has been processed.
DD_Attribute.comment: Should this be replaced by more specific elements?

DD_Attribute.name: rock_subtype
DD_Attribute.definition: The rock_subtype element identifies the rock subtype of the specimen.
DD_Attribute.comment: Rock_subtype does not have enumerated values because there are too many to list.

DD_Attribute.name: rock_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The rock_type element identifies the type of rock the specimen is.
DD_Attribute.comment: Original scheme had igneous and not igneous.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Igneous value indicates that the specimen is volatile-poor and was formed by the cooling of magma or lava.
The Sedimentary value indicates that the specimen was formed by tbd.
The Metamorphic value indicates that the specimen was formed by tbd.

DD_Attribute.name: sampling_parameter_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The sampling_parameter_max element identifies the maximum value at which a given data item was sampled. For example, a spectrum that was measured in the 0.4 to 3.5 um spectral range would have a sampling_parameter_max value of 3.5.

DD_Attribute.name: sampling_parameter_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The sampling_parameter_min element identifies the minimum value at which a given data item was sampled. For example, a spectrum that was measured in the 0.4 to 3.5 um spectral range would have a sampling_parameter_min value of 0.4.

DD_Attribute.name: sampling_parameter_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The sampling_parameter_name element identifies the name of the parameter which determines the sampling interval of the measurement.
DD_Attribute.comment: If it would be possible for there to be another option that I'm not currently aware of, is it possible to have an "other" option that then can be filled in and added to the search list of the database site? Also, these particular values are fairly self-explanatory (i.e. if you're looking at spectra and don't know what wavelength is.....), is the value_meaning tag a necessary component of the definition, and if so, what would you suggest putting in its place? EAG - These 4 are a good start. If others are needed, we can revise the dictionary to add it.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Wavelength value means the spectrum is a function of wavelength.
The Frequency value means the spectrum is a function of frequency.
The Wavenumber value means the spectrum is a function of wavenumber.
The Time value means the spectra is a function of time.
The Angle value means the spectra is a function of angle.
The Energy value means the spectra is a function of energy.

DD_Attribute.name: sampling_units
DD_Attribute.definition: The sampling_units element identifies the units in which the sampling_parameter is measured (i.e. wavelength may be measured in nm, um, etc., or frequency may be measured in cm^1, etc.)
DD_Attribute.comment: I see that for numerical values there is a units tag, but then it has its specified_unit_id... for the sampling parameter (unlike angles), there will be a variety of different units. So does putting it as its own dictionary entry make sense or not?

DD_Attribute.name: specimen_collection_location
DD_Attribute.definition: The specimen_collection_location element provides the place where the specimen was collected. Indicate if "Unknown".

DD_Attribute.name: specimen_current_location
DD_Attribute.definition: The specimen_current_location element provides the institution or laboaratory name where the specimen is currently located. Indicate if "Unknown".

DD_Attribute.name: specimen_current_owner_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The specimen_current_owner_name element identifies the individual or laboratory to whom the specimen belongs.

DD_Attribute.name: specimen_description
DD_Attribute.definition: The specimen_description element provides a short description of the specimen.

DD_Attribute.name: specimen_max_size
DD_Attribute.definition: The specimen_max_size element identifies the maximum particle size of the observed specimen.

DD_Attribute.name: specimen_min_size
DD_Attribute.definition: The specimen_min_size element identifies the minimum particle size of the observed specimen.

DD_Attribute.name: specimen_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The specimen_name element identifies the specimen as it is named where it is being kept.
DD_Attribute.comment: Need formation rule. How does this relate to unique LID?

DD_Attribute.name: spectral_range
DD_Attribute.definition: The spectral_range element identifies the general spectral range which the product covers (i.e. VNIR, VNIR-MIR, etc.)

DD_Attribute.name: synthetic_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The synthetic_type element identifies the process by which the specimen was produced synthetically.
DD_Attribute.comment: Same question as natural_origin. Also, I'm going to need Ray to fill in these value_meanings because I don't know what these things mean.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: tbd
tbd
tbd
The From Natural value indicates a natural product chemically or mineralogically altered by a laboratory treatment (e.g., heating). Does not include size and magnetic separates of natural samples.
tbd

DD_Attribute.name: volatile_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The volatile_type element indicates whether the material was volatile-poor (less than 2.0% LOI) or volatile-rich (greater than 2.0% LOI).

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The Poor value indicates the specimen had less than 2.0% LOI.
The Rich value indicates the specimen had greater than 2.0% LOI.
The Unknown value indicates the specimen's volatile type is unknown.

DD_Class.name: Measurement_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: The Measurement_Parameters class contains attributes relevant to a single measurement of a specimen.

DD_Class.name: Specimen_Classification
DD_Class.definition: The Specimen_Classification class provides information about how a specimen has been classified.

DD_Class.name: Synthetic_Specimen
DD_Class.definition: The Synthetic_Specimen class provides classification information about a specimen with a synthetic origin. It is a subclass of the Specimen_Classification class.

DD_Class.name: Natural_Specimen
DD_Class.definition: The Natural_Specimen class provides classification information about a specimen with a natural origin. It is a subclass of the Specimen_Classification class.

DD_Class.name: Specimen_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: The Specimen_Parameters class provides information about a specimen for which measurements have been made.

DD_Class.name: Spectral_Library_Product
DD_Class.definition: The Spectral_Library_Product class provides information about a data product in the Spectral Library.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: In the Specimen_Classification class, if the material_origin is Synthetic, then the subclass Synthetic_Specimen must be present, else if the material_origin is Natural, then the subclass Natural_Specimen must be present.
In the Natural_Specimen class, if material_type is Mineral, then the attribute mineral_type must be present.
In the Natural_Specimen class, if material_type is Rock, then the attribute rock_type must be present.
In the Natural_Specimen class, if the attribute material_subtype is present, then the attribute material_type must also be present.
In the Natural_Specimen class, if the attribute mineral_subtype is present, then the attribute mineral_type must also be present.
In the Natural_Specimen class, if the attribute rock_subtype is present, then the attribute rock_type must also be present.
